name: New Orleans Pelicans
history: The franchise was originally the Charlotte Hornets, relocating to New Orleans in 2002 before rebranding as the Pelicans in 2013 to better reflect local Louisiana culture. During the mid-2000s, the team played several home games in Oklahoma City following the devastation of Hurricane Katrina. The transition to the Pelicans brought a new color scheme of navy, gold, and red, inspired by the state flag and the festive spirit of the city. Today, the team is focused on building a sustainable contender around versatile young stars in the heart of the Gulf South.
fun_facts: The 'Pelican' name was chosen because it is the state bird of Louisiana.
Chris Paul led the league in assists per game twice while playing for New Orleans.
Their original mascot, 'Pierre the Pelican,' was redesigned in 2014 because fans thought the first version was too scary.
New Orleans is the smallest market in the NBA by TV household size.
During Hurricane Katrina, the team was temporarily forced to play home games in Oklahoma City for two seasons.
